results.title: Live Updates: Israel Strikes Hezbollah Stronghold in Attempt to Kill Leader
results.abstract: Israeli officials say the country’s warplanes destroyed an underground bunker in a residential area after receiving information that the group’s leader, Hassan Nasrallah, was convening a meeting there. Several apartment buildings were flattened.

results.title: Inside the Lebanese Valley Where Israel Is Bombarding Hezbollah
results.abstract: The Bekaa Valley, a Hezbollah bastion in eastern Lebanon, had mostly been spared over 11 months of war. But The New York Times saw widespread devastation there after intense Israeli airstrikes this week.
results.byline: By Christina Goldbaum, Hwaida Saad and Diego Ibarra Sanchez

multimedia.caption: A man surveys the destruction left by an Israeli airstrike in Baalbek, Lebanon, on Wednesday.

results.title: The Wily Spy Who Risked His Life to Meet North Korea’s Secretive Leader
results.abstract: Park Chae-so was so successful in infiltrating the North that Kim Jong-il, the enigmatic ruler, once gifted him blueberry wine. So why was the celebrated undercover agent later jailed by South Korea?
org_facet: Ministry of State Security of the People's Republic of China

multimedia.caption: “Whenever I visited the North, I knew my life was on the line,” said Park Chae-so, a South Korean spy who met with the then-leader of North Korea, Kim Jong-il.

results.title: Pope Francis Is Met With Anger Over Sexual Abuse on Visit to Belgium
results.abstract: During a trip to Luxembourg and Belgium, Francis spoke with 15 people who were abused by Roman Catholic clergy.
results.byline: By Jenny Gross and Emma Bubola

multimedia.caption: Pope Francis met with King Philippe, second from right, and Queen Mathilde of Belgium, left, in Brussels on Friday. He was also met with survivors of church sexual abuse.

results.title: Westminster Abbey’s Brontë Plaque Had a Typo for 85 Years. It’s Fixed Now.
results.abstract: Punctuation delayed, but not denied: A memorial to Charlotte, Emily and Anne Brontë at Poets’ Corner in the celebrated London church finally gets its accent marks.

results.title: What’s at Stake in Austria’s General Election
results.abstract: Austrians will head to the polls on Sunday to elect a new Parliament, with the Freedom Party in position to potentially form a far-right government for the first time since World War II.

multimedia.caption: Campaign posters for the People’s Party and the Freedom Party in Vienna.
Campaign posters for the People’s Party and the Freedom Party in Vienna.
Campaign posters for the People’s Party and the Freedom Party in Vienna.

results.title: Deal to Reopen Libya’s Central Bank Eases Fears of Renewed Conflict
results.abstract: A standoff over control of the bank had destabilized the country’s economy and raised the prospect of fresh fighting between Libya’s eastern and western factions.
results.byline: By Vivian Yee and Islam Al-Atrash

multimedia.caption: At a bank in Misrata, in western Libya, in August. The central bank dispute had frozen the banking system for most Libyans.
At a bank in Misrata, in western Libya, in August. The central bank dispute had frozen the banking system for most Libyans.

results.title: Japan’s Governing Party Selects New Prime Minister
results.abstract: Shigeru Ishiba, a former defense minister known for his plainspoken opinions, will replace Fumio Kishida next week.
results.byline: By Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno

results.title: This Is What Can Land You in Jail for Sedition in Hong Kong
results.abstract: Three men were the first to be convicted under the city’s recently expanded national security law, which has greatly curtailed political speech.

results.title: After 44 Years on Death Row, Japanese Man Is Exonerated at Age 88
results.abstract: Iwao Hakamada is believed to be the world’s longest-serving inmate given a death sentence.
results.byline: By Motoko Rich and Hisako Ueno

multimedia.caption: Iwao Hakamada going for a walk with a supporter in Hamamatsu, Japan, on Wednesday. He was released from prison 10 years ago and granted a retrial.

results.title: As a Finnish Zoo Returns Pandas to China, It Blames Costs, Not Geopolitics
results.abstract: Two pandas are heading back to China eight years early amid lower-than-hoped-for visitor numbers at a zoo in rural Finland, and after the pair didn’t produce a cub.
results.byline: By Amelia Nierenberg and Johanna Lemola

results.title: Israel Bombs Residential Site in Effort to Kill Hezbollah Leader
results.abstract: The strike came barely an hour after the Israeli prime minister, Benjamin Netanyahu, delivered a fiery address to the U.N. General Assembly.
results.byline: By Ronen Bergman, Julian E. Barnes, Liam Stack, Farnaz Fassihi and Michael Levenson

results.title: Israeli Strikes Destroyed 4 Large Apartment Buildings in Beirut, Videos Show
results.abstract: Visual evidence analyzed by The New York Times shows that nearby buildings were damaged in the attacks, which targeted Hezbollah’s leader. The extent of the destruction is not yet clear.
results.byline: By Christiaan Triebert, Devon Lum, Aric Toler and Bora Erden

results.title: U.S.-Led Coalition in Iraq to Wind Down Its Mission
results.abstract: The United States has 2,500 troops in Iraq who served as a bulwark against attacks by a resurgent Islamic State.
results.byline: By Alissa J. Rubin, Helene Cooper and Eric Schmitt
des_facet: United States Defense and Military Forces
org_facet: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

multimedia.caption: The United States and Iraq said they had agreed to conclude the coalition’s military mission in Iraq “over the next twelve months, and no later than the end of September 2025.”
The United States and Iraq said they had agreed to conclude the coalition’s military mission in Iraq “over the next twelve months, and no later than the end of September 2025.”

results.abstract: In a fraught meeting in May, top officials at the World Anti-Doping Agency were warned that a computer glitch might allow athletes accused of doping to compete at the Paris Games.

results.title: Booby Traps, Pager Attacks and the Law of War
results.abstract: After Israel detonated pagers and walkie-talkies in Lebanon, a fierce debate began about whether the attacks violated international law. A U.N. treaty from 1996 offers an answer.

results.title: Israel’s New Campaign Against Hezbollah Started With Raid in Syria
results.abstract: An attack on a secret weapons lab was one of the most daring Israeli operations against the Iranian proxy group in years, covert in name only.

multimedia.caption: The aftermath of Israeli strikes on Masyaf, Syria, this month. The area is only about 30 miles from the Lebanese border, which is why, Israeli and American officials say, Hezbollah manufactures weapons there instead of in Iran.
